required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Viaskin Peanut in Children With Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-Mediated Peanut Allergy
clinical_study.official_title: A Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Randomized Phase 3 Pivotal Trial to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of Peanut Epicutaneous Immunotherapy With Viaskin Peanut in Peanut-allergic Children

brief_summary.textblock: The PEPITES study evaluates the efficacy and safety of Viaskin Peanut 250 µg peanut protein to induce desensitization to peanut in peanut-allergic children 4 through 11 years of age after a 12-month treatment by epicutaneous immunotherapy (EPIT).

primary_outcome.measure: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in the Overall Population
primary_outcome.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of standardized blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed in the overall population.

secondary_outcome.measure: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in Each Screening ED Subgroup
secondary_outcome.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented below. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed for each separate screening ED subgroup.

secondary_outcome.measure: Cumulative Reactive Dose (CRD) of Peanut Protein at Baseline and Month 12
secondary_outcome.description: The CRD was calculated as the sum of all doses given (including any repeated and partial doses). The median CRD of peanut protein at baseline and Month 12 is presented. Analysis was performed using the modified baseline observation carried forward method to impute missing data at Month 12.

other_outcome.measure: Relative Change From Baseline in Peanut-specific Immunoglobulin E (IgE) Over Time
other_outcome.description: Venous blood samples were drawn to assess peanut-specific IgE levels at baseline and Months 3, 6 and 12. The median relative changes from baseline in IgE levels for each timepoint are presented. Relative change from baseline=100×(value at the visit-value at baseline)/value at baseline.

other_outcome.measure: Relative Changes From Baseline in Peanut-specific Immunoglobulin G4 Subtype (IgG4) Over Time
other_outcome.description: Venous blood samples were drawn to assess peanut-specific IgG4 levels at baseline and Months 3, 6 and 12. The median relative changes from baseline in IgG4 levels for each timepoint are presented. Relative change from baseline=100×(value at the visit-value at baseline)/value at baseline.

intervention.description: Cutaneous patch containing an inactive deposit manufactured to mimic peanut extract

facility.name: University of California, Rady Children's Hospital
Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago
The University of North Carolina - Chapell Hill
Baylor College of Medicine - Texas Children's Hospital
Centre de Recherche Appliquée en Allergie de Québec (CRAAQ)

results_reference.citation: Fleischer DM, Greenhawt M, Sussman G, Bégin P, Nowak-Wegrzyn A, Petroni D, Beyer K, Brown-Whitehorn T, Hebert J, Hourihane JO, Campbell DE, Leonard S, Chinthrajah RS, Pongracic JA, Jones SM, Lange L, Chong H, Green TD, Wood R, Cheema A, Prescott SL, Smith P, Yang W, Chan ES, Byrne A, Assa'ad A, Bird JA, Kim EH, Schneider L, Davis CM, Lanser BJ, Lambert R, Shreffler W. Effect of Epicutaneous Immunotherapy vs Placebo on Reaction to Peanut Protein Ingestion Among Children With Peanut Allergy: The PEPITES Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA. 2019 Mar 12;321(10):946-955. doi: 10.1001/jama.2019.1113.

Greenhawt M, Kim EH, Campbell DE, Green TD, Lambert R, Fleischer DM. Improvements in eliciting dose across baseline sensitivities following 12 months of epicutaneous immunotherapy (EPIT) in peanut-allergic children aged 4 to 11 years. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2020 Oct;8(9):3219-3221. doi: 10.1016/j.jaip.2020.05.030. Epub 2020 Jun 2.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This Phase III study was conducted in participants aged 4 to 11 years old with peanut allergy at 31 active centers in Australia, Canada, Germany, Ireland and USA. Participants were randomized in a 2:1 ratio to receive DBV712 250 micrograms (μg) (Viaskin® Peanut 250 μg) or placebo.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Overall maximum study duration for each participant was approximately 61 weeks (6-week screening period, 53-week treatment period and 2-week follow-up period). At the first screening visit, participants underwent a double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge (DBPCFC) up to a highest dose of 300 milligrams (mg) peanut protein to confirm their allergy and their entry peanut eliciting dose (ED).

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

baseline.population: The intent-to-treat (ITT) population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

measure.title: Screening ED Subgroup
measure.description: Screening ED Subgroup 1: participants with a screening ED of 1 mg, 3 mg or 10 mg peanut protein. Screening ED Subgroup 2: participants with a screening ED of 30 mg, 100 mg or 300 mg peanut protein.

outcome.title: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in the Overall Population
outcome.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of standardized blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed in the overall population.
outcome.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

measure.title: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in the Overall Population
measure.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of standardized blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed in the overall population.
measure.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the difference in response rates between DBV712 250 μg group and Placebo group and 2-sided Newcombe 95% confidence interval (CI). P-value was obtained from a 2-sided 5% test to evaluate the null hypothesis of no difference in response rates between treatment groups using the Wald method. Clinical relevance was evaluated based on the lower bound of the Newcombe 95% CI of the difference in response rates ≥15%.

outcome.title: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in Each Screening ED Subgroup
outcome.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented below. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed for each separate screening ED subgroup.
outcome.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

measure.title: Difference in Percentages of Treatment Responders at Month 12; Analyzed in Each Screening ED Subgroup
measure.description: The DBPCFCs to determine ED were performed at screening and Month 12, with each challenge occurring over 2 days. The participant was gradually fed increasing amounts of blinded oral formulas containing either peanut protein (during 1 of the 2 days of the challenge), or without any peanut protein (during the other day of the challenge). A participant was defined as a treatment responder if: ED was ≥300 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 1), or ED was ≥1,000 mg peanut protein at Month 12 DBPCFC (for screening ED subgroup 2). Participants with missing treatment response at Month 12 were imputed as non-responders. The percentage of treatment responders at Month 12 is presented below. Analysis of the difference in response rates between treatment groups is presented in the subsequent statistical analysis table. Analysis was performed for each separate screening ED subgroup.
measure.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

analysis.groups_desc: Screening ED subgroup 1: Analysis of the difference in response rates between DBV712 250 μg group and Placebo group and 2-sided Newcombe 95% CI. P-value was obtained from a 2-sided 5% test to evaluate the null hypothesis of no difference in response rates between treatment groups using the Wald method. Clinical relevance was evaluated based on the lower bound of the Newcombe 95% CI of the difference in response rates >0.

Screening ED subgroup 2: Analysis of the difference in response rates between DBV712 250 μg group and Placebo group and 2-sided Newcombe 95% CI. P-value was obtained from a 2-sided 5% test to evaluate the null hypothesis of no difference in response rates between treatment groups using the Wald method. Clinical relevance was evaluated based on the lower bound of the Newcombe 95% CI of the difference in response rates >0.

outcome.title: Cumulative Reactive Dose (CRD) of Peanut Protein at Baseline and Month 12
outcome.description: The CRD was calculated as the sum of all doses given (including any repeated and partial doses). The median CRD of peanut protein at baseline and Month 12 is presented. Analysis was performed using the modified baseline observation carried forward method to impute missing data at Month 12.
outcome.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

measure.title: Cumulative Reactive Dose (CRD) of Peanut Protein at Baseline and Month 12
measure.description: The CRD was calculated as the sum of all doses given (including any repeated and partial doses). The median CRD of peanut protein at baseline and Month 12 is presented. Analysis was performed using the modified baseline observation carried forward method to impute missing data at Month 12.
measure.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized.

analysis.groups_desc: The treatment effect was estimated using the Hodges-Lehmann estimate of the difference in median CRDs at Month 12.

outcome.title: Relative Change From Baseline in Peanut-specific Immunoglobulin E (IgE) Over Time
outcome.description: Venous blood samples were drawn to assess peanut-specific IgE levels at baseline and Months 3, 6 and 12. The median relative changes from baseline in IgE levels for each timepoint are presented. Relative change from baseline=100×(value at the visit-value at baseline)/value at baseline.
outcome.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized. Only those with non-missing data were included in the analysis.

group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

The median relative changes from baseline in IgE levels for each timepoint are presented. Relative change from baseline=100×(value at the visit-value at baseline)/value at baseline.
measure.population: The ITT population was comprised of all participants who were randomized. Only those with non-missing data were included in the analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) were collected from Day 1, throughout the 53-week treatment period and additional 2-week follow-up period. Overall time frame of up to 55 weeks.
reported_events.desc: The safety population was comprised of all participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of IP. Adverse events occurring after the end of the treatment period were recorded only if the Investigator considered there was a causal relationship with the IP and as such, were considered also as TEAEs.

group.title: DBV712 250 μg
group.description: Participants applied 1 new DBV712 250 μg patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants applied 1 new placebo patch for 24 hours (±4 hours) every day for 12 months. The application duration was progressively increased to a duration of 24 hours daily over a 15-day period (6 hours during the first week, 12 hours during the second week and 24 hours from the third week onwards).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There IS an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
